case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. M/s. Shri Govind Commercial Co. P. Ltd.

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan rejecting the application under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act filed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan, rejecting the application under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act, filed by the appellant.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1958-59, the Income-tax Officer disallowed loss of Rs. 45,676 incurred by the respondent M/s. Shri Govind Commercial Co. P. Ltd., Jaipur, the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment for 1958-59, the Income-tax Officer disallowed loss of Rs. 45,676 incurred by the respondent, M s. Shri Govind Commercial Co.  P.  Ltd., Jaipur, hereinafter refereed to as the assessee,

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the loss on the ground that it was incurred in speculative transactions on a large scale in hessian and gunny bags.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that this loss was incurred in speculative transaction on a large scale in hessian and gunny bags.

facts.text: Shri M. L. Sharma admitted that the transactions were of a speculative nature since the deliveries were not taken.

anchor.surface_text: It is numbered in the order that Shri M. L. Sharma admitted that the transactions were of a speculative nature since the deliveries were number taken.

facts.text: The assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: because the assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and companytended that the admission was only to the affect that delivery of goods was number taken.

facts.text: The assessee contended before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it did not take physical delivery of the goods but received delivery orders according to the terms of the contract for purchase and made over delivery orders as per sale contracts.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, it was companytended before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that the assessee did number take physical delivery of the goods but received the delivery orders according to the terms of the companytract for purchaser and, similarly, it made over the delivery order as per the terms of the sale companytracts.

facts.text: The assessee argued that receiving and making over of delivery orders was tantamount to actual delivery or transfer of the commodity or scrips within the meaning of Explanation 2 to section 24(1).

anchor.surface_text: It was further argued that this receiving and making over of delivery orders was tantamount to actual delivery of transfer of the companymodity or scrips within the meaning of Explanation 2 to section 24 1 .

facts.text: The assessee relied on the decision of this Court in Duni Chand Rataria v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee relied on the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Rataria v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd.

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the contentions of the assessee, distinguished Duni Chand Rataria case, and upheld the order of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, however, rejected the companytentions of the assessee and, distinguishing the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case, upheld the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal accepted the assessee's contentions, held that the Supreme Court decision in Duni Chand governed, was satisfied it was not settled by payment of differences, payment made for full value, transactions not speculative.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, on appeal, accepted the companytentions and held that the decision of the Supreme Court governed the case, and that, on the facts, it was satisfied that this was number a case where the transactions were settled by payment of differences. It found that payment had been made for full value of the goods purchased, and, therefore, the transactions companyld number be regarded as speculative transactions.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the term 'scrips' in Explanation 2 to section 24(1) could refer to scrips pertaining to any commodity, not only stocks and shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the term scrips occurring in Explanation 2 to section 24 1  companyld refer to scrips pertaining to any companymodity and there was numberwarrant for saying that it should refer to stocks and shares alone.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax filed an application under section 66(1) raising two specific questions.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax thereupon filed an application under section 66 1 , raising the following two questions

facts.text: The first question: Whether, on the facts and circumstances, the Tribunal was right in holding actual delivery of commodity within Explanation 2 to section 24(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that there was actual delivery of the companymodity within the meaning of Explanation 2 to section 24 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 ?

facts.text: The second question: Whether the term 'scrips' in Explanation 2 to section 24(1) can refer to scrips pertaining to any commodity or to stocks and shares alone.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the term scrips in Explanation 2 to section 24 1  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, can refer to scrips pertaining to any companymodity or to stocks and shares alone ?

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected the section 66(1) application on the ground that the questions were settled by Duni Chand Rataria case.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected the application on the ground that the questions raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax were already well- settled by the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax filed an application under section 66(2) before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax then filed an application under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act before the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the section 66(2) application in a short order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in a short order, dismissed the application.

facts.text: The High Court held the first question covered by Duni Chand v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd., second does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard learned companynsel and are inclined to the view taken by the Tribunal that the first question which is sought to be raised is companyered by the principle of the decision of their Lordships of the Supreme Court in Duni Chand v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd. In that view of the matter, the second question does number arise at all.

facts.text: The learned Solicitor-General for revenue contends the questions are arguable points of law, first not concluded by Duni Chand, Calcutta High Court in D.M. Wadhwana distinguished it.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, who appears on behalf of the revenue, companytends that the High Court should number have rejected this application under section 66 2  because the question referred to above were arguable questions of law. He says that the first question is number companycluded by the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case. He further companytends that the Calcutta High Court has in an unreported judgment in D. M. Wadhwana v. Commissioner of Income-tax, distinguished the Supreme Court decision in Duni Chand Ratarias case

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that fairly arguable questions of law arise and directs the High Court should have directed the Tribunal to state the case and refer it; appeal accepted.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court. Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.
appeal by special leave
section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court. Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.

holdings.text: Fairly arguable questions of law arise out of the Tribunal's order and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court. Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The questions proposed are fairly arguable points of law as the first is not conclusively settled by Duni Chand Rataria (distinguished by Calcutta High Court in D.M. Wadhwana) and the second arises if the first does; High Court erred in dismissing the section 66(2) application.
